title: 109_s1735
content: The Energy Emergency Consumer Protection Act of 2005 includes provisions for unfair practices in gasoline commerce, declaring energy emergencies, enforcement measures, penalties, market transparency, and investment in alternative fuels. It also addresses preparedness for energy emergencies and actions to prevent supply disruptions. SEC. 2. UNFAIR OR DECEPTIVE ACTS OR PRACTICES IN COMMERCE RELATED TO GASOLINE AND PETROLEUM DISTILLATES. During an energy emergency declared by the President, it is illegal to sell crude oil, gasoline, or petroleum distillates at an unconscionably excessive price or taking unfair advantage to increase prices unreasonably. Factors considered include the price disparity between the product sold and its market price. During an energy emergency, it is illegal to sell crude oil, gasoline, or petroleum distillates at excessively high prices. Factors considered include the price disparity compared to market prices and whether the price reflects additional costs. It is unlawful to report false pricing information related to crude oil, gasoline, or petroleum distillates to the Federal Trade Commission. Market manipulation in connection with the purchase or sale of these products at wholesale is also prohibited. The sale of crude oil, gasoline, or petroleum distillates at wholesale is regulated by the Commission to prevent manipulative or deceptive practices. SEC. 3. DECLARATION OF ENERGY EMERGENCY. If the President determines a shortage of crude oil, gasoline, or petroleum distillates threatens the US citizens' well-being, a Federal energy emergency can be declared for up to 45 days in specific regions. The President can extend a declaration of a Federal energy emergency for up to 45 days and can do so more than once. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT UNDER FEDERAL TRADE COMMISSION ACT. The Act will be enforced by the Federal Trade Commission, prioritizing enforcement actions against companies with over $500,000,000 in annual sales of oil and petroleum products. Violations will be treated as unfair or deceptive practices under the Federal Trade Commission Act. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT AT RETAIL LEVEL BY STATE ATTORNEYS GENERAL. A State can bring a civil action in federal court to enforce the Act's provisions or impose penalties for violations related to retail sales of gasoline or petroleum distillates. The State must notify the Commission before taking legal action. The State must notify the Commission before initiating a civil action, and the Commission may intervene in the legal proceedings. The attorney general of a State retains the authority to conduct investigations and compel evidence in such cases. In a civil action brought under subsection (a), the venue shall be where the defendant operates, was authorized to do business, or is found. Process can be served without territorial limits, and a person involved in the violation may be joined in the action. State action is limited while federal action is pending. The Commission can take legal action for violations of the Act, preventing State officials from pursuing action against the same defendant. However, State officials can still enforce State laws in court. SEC. 6. PENALTIES. Civil Penalty: Violations of sections 2(b) or 2(c) of the Act may result in a civil penalty of up to $1,000,000, while violations of section 2(a) may result in a penalty of up to $3,000,000. Penalties will be assessed in the same manner as civil penalties under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Each day of a continuing violation will be considered a separate offense. Violation of section 2(a) of this Act may result in a criminal penalty of up to $1,000,000 fine, 5 years imprisonment, or both. The seriousness of the violation and efforts to remedy harm will be considered by the Commission. SEC. 7. EFFECT ON OTHER LAWS. This Act does not limit the Commission's authority under the Federal Trade Commission Act or any other law. SEC. 8. MARKET TRANSPARENCY FOR CRUDE OIL, GASOLINE, AND PETROLEUM DISTILLATES. The Federal Trade Commission is mandated to promote price transparency in wholesale markets for crude oil and essential petroleum products, ensuring fair competition and consumer protection. This includes disseminating timely information on availability and prices to various stakeholders, aiming to prevent anticompetitive practices. The Commission aims to protect consumers and competitive markets from collusion and anticompetitive behaviors by withholding information that could harm market operations or security. They can obtain information from market participants and rely on external entities to disclose information under certain conditions. The Commission may establish an electronic information system if existing price publications are inadequate, but this will not affect current electronic information filing requirements. They aim to ensure price transparency by relying on existing publishers and providers, with a de minimus exception in place. The Commission may establish an electronic information system for price transparency, with a de minimus exception in place. They will also cooperate with other federal agencies for information sharing and coordination. Within 180 days of enactment, the Commission will start a rulemaking process to establish necessary rules for this section without limiting the jurisdiction of the CFTC under the Commodity Exchange Act. SEC. 9. REPORT ON UNITED STATES ENERGY EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS. The Federal Trade Commission will report to Congress on the potential impacts of disruptions in oil production, refining capacity, and global oil supplies. The report will include projections of economic impacts and recommendations for remedies under different scenarios. SEC. 10. The Comptroller General will investigate major oil companies and automobile manufacturers' investments in alternative fuels every 4 years. The report will assess their efforts to diversify motor vehicle fuel options. The National Academy of Sciences will review expenditures and activities of companies with over $500,000,000 in annual sales of oil products to protect the energy supply system from various disruptions. This includes preparing for increased hurricane activity in vulnerable coastal areas. The Federal Trade Commission is authorized to receive necessary funds for implementing this Act.
